para.p:
Let
N
be the set of positive integers. We say that a set is countable if it is bijective with a subset of
N
; thus a finite set is countable. In this note I do not presume unless I say so that any set is countable or that any topological space is separable. A neighborhood of a point in a topological space is a set that contains an open set that contains the point; one reason why it can be handy to speak about neighborhoods of a point rather than just open sets that contain the point is that the set of all neighborhoods of a point is a filter, whereas it is unlikely that the set of all open sets that contain a point is a filter.

A partially ordered set is a set
J
and a binary relation
≤
on
J
that is reflexive (
≤ α α
), antisymmetric (if both
≤ α β
and
≤ β α
then
= α β
), and transitive (if both
≤ α β
and
≤ β γ
then
≤ α γ
). 1 1 footnote 1 Paul R. Halmos, Naive Set Theory, §14. A directed set is a partially ordered set
( J , ≤ )
such that if
∈
α , β
J
then there is some
∈ γ J
such that
≤ α γ
and
≤ β γ
. If
X
is a topological space, a net in
X
is a function from some directed set to
X
. If
: z
→ J X
is a net in
X
and
N
is a subset of
X

z
is eventually in
N
if there is some
∈ α J
such that
≤ α β

∈
⁢ z
( β )
N

z
converges to
∈ x X
if for every neighborhood of
x
the net is eventually in that neighborhood. The importance of the notion of a net is that if
X
and
Y
are topological spaces and
f
is a function
→ X Y
then
f
is continuous if and only if for every
∈ x X
and for every net
: z
→ J X
that converges to
x
, the net
:
∘ f z
→ J Y
converges to
⁢ f
( x )
. 2 2 footnote 2 James R. Munkres, Topology, second ed., p. 188.

Bessel’s inequality 8 8 footnote 8 John B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 15, Theorem 4.8. states that if

p.text:
If
H

E

H

∈ h H

0

para.p: Let

Math.text: E _ n = conditional-set@(e element-of E, absolute-value@(list@(h, e)) >= 1 / n)

para.p:
If
E n
were infinite, let
{
e j
:
∈ j N
}
be a subset of it, and this gives us a contradiction by (). Therefore each
E n
is finite. But if
≠
⟨ h , e ⟩
0
then there is some
n
such that
≥
|
⟨ h , e ⟩
|
1 n
, so

Math.text: E = ((union _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ n)

para.p:
Therefore
E
is countable. ∎
Bessel’s inequality makes sense for an orthonormal set of any cardinality in a Hilbert space, rather than just for a countable orthonormal set.

p.text:

section.title: 4Convergence of unordered sums in the strong operator topology

para.p:
Let
H
be a Hilbert space and let
⁢ B
( H )
be the set of bounded linear maps
→ H H
. It is straightforward to check that
⁢ B
( H )
is a normed space with the operator norm
=
∥ T ∥
sup
≤
∥ h ∥
1
∥
⁢ T h
∥
. (In fact it is a Banach space, actually a Banach algebra, actually a
C *
-algebra; each of these statements implies the previous one.) The strong operator topology on
⁢ B
( H )
can be characterized in the following way: a net
: f
→ I
⁢ B
( H )
converges to
∈ T
⁢ B
( H )
in the strong operator topology if for all
∈ h H
the net
⁢ f
( i )
h
converges to
⁢ T h
in
H
. 9 9 footnote 9 For the strong operator topology see John B. Conway, A Course in Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 256.

If
I
is a set,
F
is the set of all finite subsets of
I
, and
: f
→ I
⁢ B
( H )
is a function, define
: S
→ F
⁢ B
( H )
by

Math.text: S * F = (sum _ (i element-of I))@(f * i) element-of B * H

para.p:
S
is a net in
⁢ B
( H )
, and if the net converges to
∈ T
⁢ B
( H )
in the strong operator topology we say that the unordered sum
∑
∈ i I
⁢ f
( i )
converges strongly to
T
. To say that the net
S
converges to
T
in the strong operator topology is to say that if
∈ h H
then
∑
∈ i I
⁢ f
( i )
h
converges to
⁢ T h
in
H
.

If
∈
f , g
H
, we define
:
⊗ f g
→ H H
by

Math.text: (f tensor-product g) * h = list@(h, g) * f

para.p:
It is apparent that
⊗ f g
is linear, and

Math.text: norm@((f tensor-product g) * h) = norm@(list@(h, g) * f) = absolute-value@(list@(h, g)) * norm@(f) less= norm@(h) * norm@(g) * norm@(f)

para.p:
so
≤
∥
⊗ f g
∥
⁢
∥ f ∥
∥ g ∥
, giving
∈
⊗ f g
⁢ B
( H )
. Additionally,

Math.tex: \langle f\otimes g(h_{1}),h_{2}\rangle=\langle\langle h_{1},g\rangle f,h_{2}% \rangle=\langle h_{1},g\rangle\langle f,h_{2}\rangle=\langle h_{1},\langle h_{% 2},f\rangle g\rangle=\langle h_{1},g\otimes f(h_{2})\rangle,
Math.text: list@((f tensor-product g) * h _ 1, h _ 2) = list@(list@(h _ 1, g) * f, h _ 2) = list@(h _ 1, g) * list@(f, h _ 2) = list@(h _ 1, list@(h _ 2, f) * g) = list@(h _ 1, (g tensor-product f) * h _ 2)

para.p:
showing that
=
(
⊗ f g
)
*
⊗ g f
.

p.text:
If
H
is a Hilbert space,
E
is an orthonormal set in
H
, and
P
is the orthogonal projection onto
⋁ E
, then
∑
∈ e E
⊗ e e
converges strongly to
P
.

para.p:
Let
∈ h H
. By Theorem there are only countably many
∈ e E
such that
≠

0

{
e n
:

}
. By Bessel’s inequality,

Math.text: (sum _ (e element-of E))@((absolute-value@(list@(h, e))) ^ 2) = (sum _ (n element-of N))@((absolute-value@(list@(h, e _ n))) ^ 2) = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(list@(h, e _ n))) ^ 2) less= (norm@(h)) ^ 2

Let
F

N

If

e n

Math.tex: \displaystyle\left\|S(F)-S(G)\right\|^{2}=\left\|\sum_{n\in F}\langle h,e_{n}% \rangle e_{n}-\sum_{n\in G}\langle h,e_{n}\rangle e_{n}\right\|^{2}=\sum_{n\in% (F\cup G)\setminus(F\cap G)}\left\|\langle h,e_{n}\rangle e_{n}\right\|^{2}=% \sum_{n\in(F\cup G)\setminus(F\cap G)}|\langle h,e_{n}\rangle|^{2}\leq\sum_{n=% N+1}^{\infty}|\langle h,e_{n}\rangle|^{2}<\epsilon^{2}.
Math.text: (norm@(S * F - S * G)) ^ 2 = (norm@((sum _ (n element-of F))@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n) - (sum _ (n element-of G))@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n))) ^ 2 = (sum _ (n element-of (F union G) set-minus (F intersection G)))@((norm@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n)) ^ 2) = (sum _ (n element-of (F union G) set-minus (F intersection G)))@((absolute-value@(list@(h, e _ n))) ^ 2) less= ((sum _ (n = N + 1)) ^ infinity)@((absolute-value@(list@(h, e _ n))) ^ 2) less epsilon ^ 2
(norm@(S * F - S * G)) ^ 2

Math.text: (norm@((sum _ (n element-of F))@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n) - (sum _ (n element-of G))@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n))) ^ 2

epsilon ^ 2

Math.text: (limit _ (N to infinity))@(((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ N)@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n)) = v

If
∈ m N

Math.text: (limit _ (N to infinity))@(((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ N)@(list@(h, e _ n) * list@(e _ n, e _ m))) = list@(v, e _ m)

para.p: which is

Math.text: list@(h, e _ m) = list@(v, e _ m)

Let

Math.text: (sum _ (e element-of E))@((e tensor-product e) * h) = (sum _ (e element-of E))@(list@(h, e) * e) = (sum _ (n element-of N))@(list@(h, e _ n) * e _ n) = P * h

para.p:
showing that the unordered sum

In particular, if
E

H

∑

id H
.
